STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 7, 2020
Katherine Page-Sander
Hands Across The Water
Suite 200
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
RE: License #: CB810201161
Hands Across The Water
Suite 200
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
Dear Ms. Page-Sander:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on September
21, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please identify what steps from the prior CAP will be revised to ensure
compliance going forward.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivisions (b) of
this subrule.
One of six foster homes did not have the required hours of training completed for
their 2020 annual review. A CAP was not developed by the agency to bring the
foster parent into compliance.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of eight foster care case files did not have a dental exam completed within 90
days of placement. The youth was placed on 7/15/19 and a dental exam was not
completed until 10/28/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 777-08C Parent agency treatment plan and service agreement
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and service
agreement…
CI 17-099
4

When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from all
appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and older for
foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile justice, should
be obtained before the corresponding court hearing. All treatment
plans with a report date of August 1, 2017, or later must have
signatures from all appropriate case members within 30 days of
the report date.
Seven of twenty-five treatment plans had late or missing signatures.
File one: 4/3/20 PATP was not signed by the parent until 7/13/20.
File two: 6/24/20 PATP was missing the caregiver signature.
File three: 10/10/19 PATP was not signed by the foster parent until 11/21/19.
File four: 10/25/19 PATP signed by parents and caregiver 12/18/19. 1/23/20 PATP
provided late via mail on 5/7/20, no signatures. 4/22/20 PATP mailed 5/8/20, no
signatures. 7/21/20 PATP mailed on 8/5/20; no signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal dated 7/16/19, CAP approved 7/29/19.
FOM 722-09 Updated service plan
Supervisory approval- prior to finalizing, the USP along with the
required assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and
approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face
meeting with the worker. Case service plan approval process
requires the foster care supervisor to review and approve the USP
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
Four of twenty-five service plans were not approved by the supervisor within the 14
day requirement.
File one: USP completed 7/15/20, approved by the supervisor 8/10/20.
File two: USP completed 7/3/20, approved by the supervisor 7/23/20.
File three: USP completed 11/11/19, approved by the supervisor 12/6/19.
File four: USP completed 7/21/20, approved by the supervisor 8/5/20.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal dated 7/16/19, CAP approved 7/29/19.
Interim dated 7/23/18, CAP approved 8/6/18.
FOM 722-06b Family team meeting
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers, foster
parents, children, youth, and may also include extended family,
friends, neighbors, community-based service providers, community
5

representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian children, or other
professionals involved with the family.
One of nine foster care and IL case files did not meet this requirement. The file was
missing one FTM prior to the July 2020 USP. The file was also missing the 1105
report for the April 2020 FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION
Renewal dated 7/16/19, CAP approved 7/29/19.
Interim dated 7/23/18, CAP approved 8/6/18.
IV. ANALYST INFORMATION
There were no safety alerts for this agency.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Rule 327 (1c) Special Evaluations. TA was provided to the facility regarding an SE
that was completed in which it was alleged the foster parents accepted an IL
placement from another agency. The interviews with the foster parents, and the
current and former children placed in the home concluded that the alleged IL youth
never lived in the home. However, the IL youth’s caseworker from another agency
indicated that she had visit the youth at their home. The IL youth was not
interviewed. When asked why the IL youth was not interviewed, the agency
indicated that the IL caseworker did not have any documentation or other
information to confirm her visits with the IL youth at the foster home. Due to the
foster parents and other household members denying the placement, the agency felt
the information was sufficient to conclude the investigation. The agency was advised
that an interview with the IL youth should have been attempted to fully complete the
investigation.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 801 Medical Passports. The facility completed quarterly passports on a
quarterly, calendar schedule (Q1- Jan to March, Q2- April to June, Q3- July to Sept,
Q4- Oct to Dec). Policy was reviewed as there was a question about what “quarterly”
meant: a quarterly calendar, or every 90 days. The policy office was contact and
stated there is not a definition for quarterly. However, best practice would be for the
updated passports to align with the 90 day service plans. The agency was advised
of this clarification from the policy office.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
6

The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
 Interim review dated 7/23/18, CAP approved 8/6/18 and renewal report dated
7/16/19, CAP approved 7/29/19. The 2018 evaluation found 15 violations and
the 2019 evaluation found 14 violations. During this review only 5 violations
were found, including 3 repeat violations. While there were repeats, the
occurrence of each repeat was low and some timeliness issues could be
attributed to the challenges of completing tasks during the COVID-19
pandemic. Overall, it appears the agency CAPs have been effective in
reducing the number of violations.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract. Upon receipt of an acceptable
corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a regular license.
September 28, 2020
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 7, 2020
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
